article-meta.issue-title: University of Pennsylvania Conference on Statistical Issues in Clinical Trials: Emerging statistical issues in the conduct and monitoring of clinical trials

body.p: This issue of Clinical Trials contains the proceedings of the fourth in a series of symposia held at the University of Pennsylvania on current statistical issues in clinical trials. This symposium, held in spring 2011, focused on new approaches to manage the conduct of clinical trials, a topic highly relevant to the ever-increasing concerns about clinical trial efficiency. Although most of the recent discussion about trial efficiency has centered on issues in trial design (e.g., adaptive designs, designs for targeted therapies), there are many other aspects of trial conduct to which the quest for increased efficiency could be directed. Two talks in this symposium addressed approaches to quality control, an area to which industries in particular allocate huge resources and which has been the target of critiques by eminent clinical trialists [1,2]. Other talks addressed ways to develop more accurate sample size estimates, methods to predict accrual rates, use of incentives to promote adherence in trials, how to estimate treatment effects in trials stopped early, issues in studies using adaptive designs, and practical issues in evaluating multiple endpoints. Expert panels provided thoughtful commentary on the presentations, and there were insightful questions and comments from the floor; these discussions are included along with the papers.

The Penn conference series is aimed at facilitating advances in approaches to the statistical design, implementation and analysis of clinical trials. Earlier conferences in this series focused on proof-of-concept studies and ‘go–no go’ decision making [3], development of targeted therapies [4], and comparative effectiveness studies [5].
